p: Different EO exhibits different antimicrobial properties; this may include antibacterial activity. There are different mechanisms of action that cause the inhibition of microbial growth, which are still not fully known [ 51, 65]. The antibacterial activity of EO refers to their ability to inhibit or inactivate bacterial growth [ 66, 67]. Several studies have reported that some plants and EO such as clove, thyme, rosemary, oregano, cinnamon, and pimento showed potent inhibitory effects against various bacterial pathogens [ 68, 69, 70, 71, 72]. Studies suggests that phenolics found in EO such as eugenol, carvacrol, and thymol are mainly responsible for their antibacterial action against different bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus cereus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli; phenolics pertains to the aromatic feature of EO [ 47, 50, 51, 60].
